chapters.content:
Septic Abortion

Septic abortion is diagnosed by the following signs:

Tender uterus

AND

Abnormal, foul smelling vaginal discharge

OR

Rebound tenderness

OR

Any signs of shock (systolic blood pressure below 90) or pre-shock (pulse above 90).

OR

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.

At signs of septic abortion or at excessive vaginal bleeding:

Evacuation of the uterus must be performed with no delay!Do not delay by awaiting “antibiotic coverage”!
CALL FOR HELP!

Airway

Position so airway is not occluded or at risk of aspiration.

Breathing

If gasping or absent ventilate with bag and mask.

Circulation

Insert 2 wide bore IV cannulas.

Give at least 2L fluids IV, normal saline or Ringer’s lactate fast.

Insert indwelling urine catheter to monitor in- and output.

Drugs

Give antibiotics intravenous according to local guidelines, for example:

Ampicillin 1 g/6 hrs.

AND

Gentamicin 80 mg/12 hrs.

AND

Metronidazole 500 mg/8 hrs.

This must not delay the lifesaving EVACUATION of the uterus.Give antibiotics while you start the procedure.If antibiotics are not available, perform evacuation and give antibiotics afterwards.

Evacuate Uterus

Give appropriate analgesia then evacuate using no-touch technique.

Until 12-14 weeks of gestation Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) is the preferred method.

At a higher gestational age evacuation is by Dilatation and Curettage (D&C) and should be performed in a referral facility.

PERIPHERAL LEVEL

If at a peripheral level without possibility of performing manual vacuum aspiration: Give Antibiotics intra musculary and refer IMMEDIATELY

1. Monitor vital signs and urine output closely until stable.
  2. Treat with IV antibiotics until 48 hours after the woman is fever free, then oral antibiotics for 5-7 days.
  3. Before discharge, advise on family planning and check for sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and Usage

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine.

Diazepam is used to treat anxiety, agitation and convulsions.

Can also be used as analgesia before a painful procedure.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

Before procedure:

10 mg IV OR

10-20 mg IM OR

20 mg rectally OR

Second dose:

10 mg IV/IM/rectally

Children:

For convulsions:

give 0.5 mg/kg rectally once.

If convulsions persist after 10 minutes repeat 0.5mg/kg rectally one more time.

If convulsions persists after additional 10 min give 0.4 mg/kg intravenously maximum once.

If convulsions occur in early pregnancy or if Magnesium Sulphate toxicity occurs or Magnesium Sulphate is not available.

Loading dose IV:

Give Diazepam 10 mg IV slowly over 2 minutes.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenace dose:

Give Diazepam 40 mg in 500 ml IV fluids (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) titrated over 6-8 hours to keep the woman sedated but rousable.

Stop the maintenance dose if breathing is affected.

Assist ventilation if necessary with mask and bag.

Do not give more than 100 mg in 24 hours.

If IV access is not possible (e.g. during convulsion), give Diazepam rectally.

Loading dose rectally:

Give 20 mg (4 ml) in a 10 ml syringe (or urinary catheter):

Remove the needle, lubricate the barrel and insert the syringe into the rectum to half its length.

Discharge the contents and leave the syringe in place, holding the buttocks together for 10 minutes to prevent expulsion of the drug.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenance dose:

Give additional 10 mg (2 ml) every hour during transport.

Contraindications

Alcohol intoxication.

Severe respiratory or liver illness.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are drowsiness and confusion.

Uncommon reactions are muscle weakness, coordination difficulties, headache, concentration difficulty and dizziness.

Rare reactions are respiratory depression or respiratory stop, aggression, hallucinations, psychosis, and allergic reactions.

Diazepam should not be used long term as tolerance and addiction occurs commonly.

Indications and Usage

Aminoglycoside antibiotic indicated for treatment of severe or serious bacterial infections in adults and children.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

240 mg intravenously once a day.

Children (First week of life):

2.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if term; 1.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if preterm intravenously or intramuscularly.

Treat for at least two days.

Children (Weeks 2-4 of life):

7.5 mg/kg per dose once a day intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to aminoglycosides.

Treatment should not be more than 3 days if the patient is suffering from renal failure (oliguria or elevated creatinine).

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are kidney affection, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

Uncommon reactions are liver affection, increased or lowered blood pressure, respiratory depression, lowered platelets, joint and muscle pain, depression, coordination disturbances, skin rash, itching, visual disturbances, urticaria and anaphylactic reactions.

Rare reactions are deafness, hair loss, low urine production and necrosis of the skin.

Indications and Usage

Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).

It works by reducing hormones that cause inflammation and pain in the body.

Ibuprofen is used to reduce fever and treat pain or inflammation caused by many conditions such as headache, toothache, back pain, arthritis, menstrual cramps, or minor injury.

Dosage and Administration

For pain relief give 400-600 mg. Ibuprofen orally.

The maximum amount of Ibuprofen for adults is 800 milligrams per dose or 3,200 mg per day (4 maximum doses).

Use only the smallest amount needed to get relief from your pain, swelling, or fever.

Contraindications

Ibuprofen is contraindicated for use in patients with:

Known hypersensitivity or idiosyncratic reaction to Ibuprofen (or any of the other ingredients in the product) known hypersensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs.

Asthma that is aspirin or NSAID sensitive.

Active gastrointestinal bleeding or peptic ulceration.

Adverse Reactions

Adverse effects include nausea, dyspepsia, diarrhoea, constipation, gastrointestinal ulceration/bleeding, headache, dizziness, rash, salt and fluid retention, and hypertension.

Infrequent adverse effects include esophageal ulceration, heart failure, hyperkalemia, renal impairment, confusion, and bronchospasm. Ibuprofen can exacerbate asthma, sometimes fatally.

Indications and Usage

Metronidazole is a 5-nitroimidazole antibiotic used on obligate anaerobe bacterias and protozoes.

Treatment of anaerobic bacterial infections and trichomona vaginalis, intestinal amoebae and giardiasis.

Dosage and administration

500 mg. every 12 hours for 7 days or until 48 hours after the patient is fever free.

Contraindications

Allergy to Metronidazole.

It is very important to note, that alcohol must not be taken together with or three days following treatment with metronidazole as it can cause a severe adverse reaction.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are a taste of metal sensation, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and transient liver affection.

Uncommon reactions are joint- and muscle pain, headache and visual disturbances.

Rare reactions are pancreatitis, lowered platelets, dizziness, sensitivity disturbances, confusion and skin rash.

Anaphylactic shock is very rare.

Indications and usage

Strong opioid analgetic drug.

Dosage and administration

5-10 mg intramuscularly.

2.5-5 mg intravenously.

Can be repeated if insufficient response after 30 minutes up to a maximum dose of 60 mg over 24 hours.

Contraindications

History of severe reactions to opioids (respiratory stop).

Severe respiratory insufficiency, paralytic ileus, liver insufficiency.

Should not be given in first trimester.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, euphoria, drowsiness, dizziness, fainting and mood disturbances.

Uncommon reactions are agitation, trembling, confusion, fits, urticaria, respiratory depression, increased or decreased pulse and constipation.

Rare reactions are hallucinations, itching, skin rash and anaphylactic reactions.

chapters.content:
Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.

MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12 weeks.

Especially at septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed with no delay.

Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.

Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.

Cleaning After Use

Step 1:

Soak instruments immediately after use

Following the procedure, decontaminate and clean all aspirators that will be reused, by first putting unlock and open jointed instruments in a 0.5 % chlorine solution for maximum 10 min.

Hereafter clean the aspirators with a brush in a soap solution. Be aware the soap solution is made of detergent and water, not hand soap.

Rinse items with clean running water to remove all detergent.

Step 2:

Clean all aspirators thoroughly in warm water and detergent, not soap.

Wear gloves and face protection.

Disassemble the aspirator by pulling the cylinder out of the valve.

Remove the cap by pressing down the cap-release tabs with one hand and pulling off the cap with the other hand.

Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.

Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.

With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.

Remove the valve liner.

Disengage the collar stop by sliding it sideways under the retaining clip, or remove the collar stop completely.

Pull the plunger completely out.

Displace the plunger O-ring by squeezing its sides and rolling it into the groove below.

Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

questions.question: Globally, how many women undergo an unsafe abortion each year?
questions.description: Globally 20 million (2 crore) women undergo an unsafe abortion.

questions.question: What is the most common life-threatening complication to abortion?
questions.description: The most common life-threatening complication to abortion is septic abortion.

questions.question: When would you suspect a complication to an unsafe abortion?
questions.description:
You suspect a complication to an unsafe abortion if:

Any woman of reproductive age has abdominal pain

Any woman of reproductive age has fever

Any woman of reproductive age has vaginal bleeding

answers.value: Any woman of reproductive age with abdominal pain
Any woman of reproductive age with fever
Only when a woman herself admits to have had an illegal abortion
Any woman of reproductive age with vaginal bleeding

questions.question: For women of reproductive age, when would you perform a urine pregnancy test?
questions.description:
I would perform a urine pregnancy test:

For all needing medical treatment – drugs might harm the foetus

For all women that did not have their menstrual periods when expected

For all woman presenting with lower abdominal pain, fever or vaginal bleeding

answers.value: For all woman presenting with lower abdominal pain, fever or vaginal bleeding
For all women that did not have their menstrual periods when expected
For all needing medical treatment – drugs might harm the foetus

questions.question: When suspecting a complication to abortion, what initial questions and tests are important?
questions.description:
The important initial questions and tests are?

Urine pregnancy test

When was last menstrual period?

What family planning method has been used?

answers.value: Consent from parents or husband to further examinations
What family planning method has been used?

questions.question: Will a woman with septic abortion always have fever?
questions.description: A woman with septic abortion do not always have fever?

questions.question: At a confirmed pregnancy, what tests are necessary?
questions.description:
At a confirmed pregnancy, I need to:

Blood pressure, pulse and temperature

Abdominal palpation

Vaginal examination

answers.value: Tendon reflexes and liver function test

questions.question: What are the signs of septic abortion on examination?
questions.description:
The signs of septic abortion on examination are:

Tender uterus.

Foul smelling discharge from the uterus

answers.value: Foul smelling discharge from the uterus

questions.question: What will you suspect at lower abdominal rebound tenderness?
questions.description:
At lower abdominal rebound tenderness you will suspect:

Appendicitis.

Septic abortion.

answers.value: Could be normal pregnancy related pain from ligaments and joints

questions.question: Can septic abortion cause death?
questions.description: Yes,  septic abortion cause death and the woman can die within hours.

answers.value: Yes, the woman can die within hours
Yes, but only after days or weeks

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Most important action at septic abortion

questions.question: What is the one most important actions at a septic abortion?
questions.description: The one most important actions at a septic abortion is evacuation of the uterus with no delay!

answers.value: Evacuation of the uterus with no delay!
Treatment for HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases

questions.question: What is true regarding septic abortion?
questions.description:
True about septic abortion is:

The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus and antibiotics will often not help much.

Evacuation of the uterus is the correct effective management.

answers.value: The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus and antibiotics will often not help much
Evacuation of the uterus is the correct effective management
Antibiotics will almost always be an effective treatment
Evacuation of the uterus is contraindicated

questions.question: Is evacuation of the uterus needed at septic abortion?
questions.description: Yes, always! And with no delay!  The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus.

answers.value: Yes, always! And with no delay! The septic abortion is like an abscess in the uterus
Only sometimes – if antibiotics have not had an effect within 24-48 hours
Often – but wait at least 6-12 hours for antibiotic coverage

questions.question: When should evacuation of the uterus be performed when septic abortion is diagnosed?
questions.description: Evacuation of the uterus should be performed immediately with no delay, when septic abortion is diagnosed– waiting increases the risk of a bad outcome.

answers.value: Immediately with no delay – waiting increases the risk of a bad outcome
After 24-48 hours of antibiotic treatment with no effect
Never perform evacuation of the uterus at a septic abortion

keyLearningPointDetails.description: AB and evacuation of the uterus

questions.question: How long should you wait to give antibiotics before performing evacuation of the uterus at a septic abortion?
questions.description:
Antibiotic coverage should not be awaited.

Antibiotics work best when given at the beginning of the procedure.

answers.value: Antibiotic coverage should not be awaited
Antibiotics work best when given at the beginning of the procedure
Evacuation should not be performed at septic abortion

questions.question: What antibiotics should be given at a septic abortion?
questions.description: Broad-spectrum antibiotics, intravenous, for example Ampicillin, Gentamicin and Metronidazole, should be given under septic abortion.

answers.value: Broad-spectrum, intravenous, for example Ampicillin, Gentamicin and Metronidazole

questions.question: How urgent is the management of a women diagnosed with septic abortion or excessive vaginal bleeding?
questions.description:
If a women is diagnosed with septic abortion or excessive vaginal bleeding management is:

Very urgent! You must act now! The uterus must be evacuated!

answers.value: Very urgent! You must act now! The uterus must be evacuated!
Urgent, Initial management with antibiotics should be started within 2-4 hours
It is not a life-or-death situation. Others might need help first
Not really urgent. They brought themselves into this situation

questions.question: At septic abortion, what is the correct order of actions?
questions.description:
At septic abortion, the correct order of actions is:

Call for help, assess airway and ensure breathing

Establish intravenous access and give fluid resuscitation 2 liters of Normal saline or Ringer’s lactate FAST

Evacuate the uterus IMMEDIATELY!

Give broad-spectrum antibiotics

answers.value: Call for help, assess airway and ensure breathing
Establish intravenous access and give fluid resuscitation 2 liters of Normal saline or Ringer’s lactate FAST

questions.question: At severe pain and a hard, “woody” abdomen which actions are correct?
questions.description:
At severe pain and a hard, “woody” abdomen following actions are correct:

There is sign of organ perforation and she needs surgery. 

If at a peripheral facility, stabilize and refer to a higher level facility.

answers.value: There is sign of organ perforation and she needs surgery.
If at a peripheral facility, stabilize and refer to a higher level facility
Give antibiotics and assess after 24 hours

questions.question: What is true about the procedure “evacuation of the uterus”?
questions.description:
Following is true about the procedure “evacuation of the uterus”:

Evacuation of the uterus is a Basic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal signal function.

It is the lifesaving procedure that must be performed by any “skilled birth attendant”.

If no possibility of performing evacuation of the uterus; give antibiotics and refer IMMEDIATELY.

answers.value: Evacuation of the uterus is a BEmONC signal function and should be performed by any "skilled birth attendant
If no possibility of performing evacuation of the uterus; give antibiotics and refer IMMEDIATELY
It should only be done at a referral hospital
It is not the highest priority at a septic abortion

questions.question: Until what gestational age can Manual Vacuum Aspiration of the uterus be performed?
questions.description: Manual Vacuum Aspiration of the uterus be performed can be performed until the gestational weeks 12-14.

questions.question: What is the size of the uterus at 12 gestational weeks?
questions.description: At 12 gestational weeks the uterus is the size of a grape-fruit.

questions.question: Preparing for Manual vacuum aspiration involves the following:
questions.description:
Preparing for Manual vacuum aspiration involves the following:

Prepare a table with sterile field for cannulas and other instruments.

Give analgesia.

answers.value: Prepare a table with sterile field for cannulas and other instruments
Inform the police if suspicious of an illegal abortion

questions.question: What could be relevant analgesic drugs for Manual Vacuum aspiration procedure?
questions.description:
Relevant analgesic drugs for Manual Vacuum aspiration procedure could be:

Paracervical block.

Diazepam.

questions.question: When preparing the Manual Vacuum Aspiration syringe the valves must be:
questions.description: When preparing the Manual Vacuum Aspiration syringe the valves must be closed.

questions.question: To apply vacuum to the Manual Vacuum aspirator syringe you should:
questions.description: To apply vacuum to the Manual Vacuum aspirator syringe you should close valves and pull plunger.

questions.question: Where should the tenaculum be inserted during Manual Vacuum Aspiration?
questions.description: The tenaculum should be inserted at the anterior lip of the cervix, during Manual Vacuum Aspiration.

answers.value: Both anterior and posterior lip of the cervix

questions.question: If you need to dilate the cervix with cannulas or dilators you:
questions.description:
If you need to dilate the cervix with cannulas or dilators you:	

Start with the thinnest and proceed to the thickest.

answers.value: Start with the thinnest and proceed to the thickest
Start with the thickest and proceed to the thinnest

questions.question: What is meant with the “no-touch-technique”?
questions.description: By the “no-touch-technique” is meant that the tip of the cannulas must touch nothing before inserted in the cervix.

answers.value: The tip of the cannulas must touch nothing before inserted in the cervix
The syringe and cannulas must remain sterile and touch nothing before inserted in the cervix
The cannulas must not be touched by the hand only by instruments
You are not allowed to touch anything non-sterile with your hands

questions.question: What is true when performing Manual Vacuum Aspiration?
questions.description:
Following is true when performing Manual Vacuum Aspiration:

The tip of the cannulas must not touch anything before inserted in the cervix.

answers.value: The tip of the cannulas must not touch anything before inserted in the cervix
The base of the cannulas must not touch anything before inserted in the cervix
The entire cannulas must not touch anything before inserted in the cervix
The entire cannulas can be touched before inserted in the cervix

questions.question: What size cannula should you use for manual vacuum aspiration?
questions.description: You should use the number equal to the gestational week for manual vacuum aspiration.

answers.value: The number equal to the gestational week

questions.question: How do you insert the cannula for manual vacuum aspiration?
questions.description: You insert the cannula for manual vacuum aspiration gently until it reaches the fundus.

answers.value: Insert gently until it reaches the fundus
Insert with a quick movement until you cannot go any further
The tip should be just inside the cervix

questions.question: Once the cannula is inserted what is the next step?
questions.description:
Once the cannula is inserted, the next step is:

Attach the syringe – then open the valves.

answers.value: Attach the syringe – then open the valves
Open the valves of the syringe and attach it
Attach the syringe and close the valves
Attach the syringe and push the plunger

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Rotate and move cannula back and forth

questions.question: With cannula inserted, syringe attached and valves opened now you:
questions.description: With cannula inserted, syringe attached and valves opened now you rotate and move the cannula back and forth.

answers.value: Rotate and move the cannula back and forth
Push the cannula as far as you can
Push the plunger in and out several times

questions.question: When do you stop suctioning during MVA?
questions.description:
You stop suctioning during MVA:

When there is no more return of tissue.

When the syringe is full in order to empty the syringe and then continue afterwards.

When there is a “gritty sensation”.

answers.value: When there is no more return of tissue
When the syringe is full in order to empty the syringe and then continue afterwards

questions.question: You can detach the syringe after suctioning, emptying it, applying the vacuum and reattaching it to the cannula for more suctioning. True or False?
questions.description: True, you can detach the syringe after suctioning, emptying it, applying the vacuum and reattaching it to the cannula for more suctioning.

questions.question: After the MVA what should you do regarding antibiotics at septic abortion?
questions.description:
After the MVA you should:

Continue broad spectrum IV antibiotics until no fever for 48 hours.

After IV antibiotics give oral ampicillin and metronidazole for 5-7 days.

answers.value: Continue broad spectrum IV antibiotics until no fever for 48 hours
After IV antibiotics give oral ampicillin and metronidazole for 5-7 days
Give oral ampicillin and metronidazole for 1-3 days

questions.question: After the emergency treatment for septic abortion what is a very important part of post abortion care?
questions.description:
After the emergency treatment for septic abortion the following is a very important part of post abortion care:

Counselling about HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases.

Counselling about family planning.

answers.value: Counselling about HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases
The parents or husband must be informed about what happened

questions.question: When sending the woman home, you advise her to come back if experiencing:
questions.description:
When sending the woman home, you advise her to come back if experiencing:

Fever.

Persistent pain.

Persistent bleeding.

questions.question: Do oral contraceptives protect against sexually transmitted diseases?
questions.description: No, oral contraceptives do not protect against sexually transmitted diseases.
